title: Hong Kong’s Hang Seng Index Battles Midlife Crisis: Boring Stocks and Blacklists
sub_head: The index and its mix of stocks will be getting a makeover
body:
The Hang Seng Index, the main barometer of Hong Kong’s $6 trillion stock market, has fallen behind the times and now faces an uncertain future.
While the Hang Seng is off to a strong start for 2021, gaining 8.1% so far, it is in some ways catching up with other markets, after a dismal year in which it underperformed other benchmarks and retreated 3.4%.
A focus on banks and insurers has held the index back. Meanwhile, U.S.-China tensions have added to the uncertainty. As of Jan. 11, new investment in products tracking the Hang Seng became off-limits to American investors, due to a U.S. government block on investment in companies it says aid China’s military.
The blacklisted stocks include some Hang Seng constituents, such as China Mobile Ltd. , and U.S. investors can’t buy funds that hold any shares in such companies.
In December, Hang Seng Indexes Co. began consulting on an overhaul. The index compiler—a unit of Hang Seng Bank Ltd. , in turn majority owned by HSBC Holdings PLC—is collecting feedback on proposed changes, including increasing the index from 52 stocks to between 65 and 80.
